#Text=Assessment of groundwater contamination from land-use/cover change in rural-urban fringe of national capital territory of Delhi (India)
#Text=Rai, Suresh Chand; Kumari, Preeti Veröffentlichungsversion / Published Version Zeitschriftenartikel / journal article Empfohlene Zitierung / Suggested Citation:

#Text=ANALELE ŞTIINTIFICE ALE SCIENTIFIC ANNALS OF UNIVERSITĂŢII „AL. I. CUZA” IAŞI “Al. I. CUZA” UNIVERSITY OF IAŞI Tom LVIII, s. II – c, Geografie 2012 Volume LVIII, s. II – c, Geography series 2012 ISSN 1223-5334 (printed version) (online version) 2284-6379 e-ISSN
#Text=© Author(s) 2012. CC Attribution 3.0 License
#Text=ASSESSMENT OF GROUNDWATER CONTAMINATION FROM LAND- USE/COVER CHANGE IN RURAL-URBAN FRINGE OF NATIONAL CAPITAL TERRYTORY OF DELHI (INDIA)
#Text=1* 2
#Text=Suresh Chand RAI and Preeti KUMARI

#Text=1 Department of Geography, Delhi School of Economics, University of Delhi, raisc1958@rediffmail.com 2 Department of Geography, Delhi School of Economics, University of Delhi, priti.dos@gmail.com Abstract: This study examines the relationship between groundwater depletion/pollution and land-use/cover change in rural-urban fringe of Delhi, where agro- ecosystems and populations are dependent on access to reliable groundwater supplies.
#Text=Results indicate a significant relationship between high proportionate decrease in groundwater and land being removed from irrigation.
#Text=The higher values of most of the parameters were found in the agricultural field and industrial area.
#Text=The study results suggest that most of the elements exceeding the general acceptable limit.
#Text=This indicates the land- use/cover change from agriculture to industrial and residential area and also the impact of excess use of chemical fertilizer/pesticides in agricultural land.
#Text=Keywords: groundwater, contamination, North-West district, Land-use/cover, Delhi, seasonal variation
#Text=I. INTRODUCTION
#Text=Water is one of the most important commodities that mankind has exploited more than any other resources for the sustenance of life.
#Text=Only 1% of the earth’s water is fresh water and more than 1.2 billion people still have no access to safe drinking water.
#Text=Eighty-five percent of total human consumptive water use is for agriculture, and food production may soon be limited by water availability (Gleick 2003; Kettle et al. 2007).
#Text=The availability of water both in terms of quality and quantity is essential for the very existence of mankind (Datta, 2005; Datta et al. 2009).

#Text=Adequate and reliable water supplies are insufficient to support current agricultural, industrial, and domestic uses, and future water use demands are predicted to increase as developing countries seek new levels of economic growth and prosperity (Jury and Vaux, 2005; Parris, 2011).

#Text=Increasing urbanization and extension of the urban boundaries into the countryside coupled with industrial growth has led to increased discharge of pollutants via drains into rivers and lakes (Kulabako et al.

#Text=In India, 90% of the household wastewater is discharged into water bodies without effective pre-treatment, leading to levels of contamination beyond the acceptable limits (Sarawgi et al. 2009; Rai and Dubey, 2009).
#Text=Groundwater is used for irrigating nearly two-thirds of the area under irrigation in the Delhi region.
#Text=Nearly 50% of the domestic and industrial supply of water is met from groundwater; the remaining is supplied by Yamuna river surface water conveyed by canals (Datta et al. 1997; Rai, 2011).

#Text=Although, the net sown area and the area sown more than once have decreased considerably due to urbanization, the remaining cropped area is about 50% of the total geographical area (Delhi Administration, 1991-92).
#Text=Thus, the large-scale need for food security and urban drinking water supply is dependent on groundwater.
#Text=It is the result of alarming degradation in water quality caused due to toxic pollutants of various kinds like organic, inorganic, and organometallics etc.
#Text=which are continuously discharged into the water bodies from domestic, agricultural and industrial sectors.
#Text=Increasing groundwater use and pollution generation has crossed the sustainable limits in many parts.
#Text=Water quality is highly variable over time and space due to both natural and human factors (Park and Kim, 2003).
#Text=Due to these spatial and temporal variations in water chemistry, a monitoring programme that will provide a representative and reliable estimation of the quality of groundwater is necessary.
#Text=So for no study has been carried out to see the correlation of land- use/cover change with groundwater contamination in this study area.
#Text=However, the only work of Datta et al. (1997) represents NO 3 and K composition in groundwater.
#Text=Thus, this research was carried out to assess the relationship between land- use/cover change and degree of pollution of groundwater quality in selected sites of rural-urban fringe of Delhi.
#Text=To assess the degree of pollution, several water quality parameters have been measured.
#Text=This region is characterised by practice of intensive agriculture for half of century.
#Text=This region is not only characterised by intensive agriculture but it also a hub of commercial and industrial activities.
#Text=Thus, the level of groundwater development has surpassed its replenishable limit with falling water-table at an alarming rate.
#Text=II. PROFILE OF THE STUDY AREA
#Text=Rural-urban fringes are characterised by a wide variety of land uses.
#Text=The study area includes rural areas, which fall in the North-West district of National Capital Territory (NCT) of Delhi beyond the corporate limit of urban regions.
#Text=North-West district of NCT Delhi has fertile soil, especially near the river and the quality of groundwater also makes the area quite suitable for cultivation.
#Text=The main road running towards Amritsar (G.T.
#Text=road) separates the district an eastern and western part.
#Text=The eastern part has relatively more land under intensive cultivation and yields better harvests, including horticulture crops.
#Text=The western part contains more urban sprawl and the soils are less fertile in some places.
#Text=Alipur block of North-West district clearly constitutes a rural-urban fringe, according to the model of urbanization (Kumari, 2011).
#Text=The NCT of Delhi presently comprises of 9 districts and 27 Tehsils.
#Text=North- West district of NCT Delhi is the largest district having an area of 440 km2 and -2 3615261total population with population density of 8298 person km in 2011.
#Text=It lies in the north-western part of NCT Delhi.
#Text=The district lies between 76°56 ́54" and 77°13 ́31" E and 28°39 ́59" and 28°52 ́42" N (Fig 1).
